headline: Jam Filled Butter Cookies
description: These dainty jelly-filled cookies are simple to make; try using a variety of jams or fruit preserves so guests can chose their favorite flavor.
name: Jam Filled Butter Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

Beat butter, sugar, and egg yolks together in a medium bowl with an electric mixer until light and fluffy; gradually mix in flour until a soft dough forms. Roll dough into 1-inch balls; place balls onto ungreased cookie sheets about 2 inches apart. Use your finger or an instrument of similar size to make a well in the center of each cookie; fill the hole with 1/2 teaspoon of preserves.
Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown on the bottom, 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from cookie sheets to cool on wire racks.

review.reviewBody: Read some previous reviews so added 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Apricot preserves was my choice and used almond extract instead of vanilla. Not crumbly, however delicate and delicious which balances the sweetness of the preserves. This photo was taken after 10 were eaten!
Made these as recipe says using apricot preserves and they were wonderful!

These turned out very nicely. I didn't have any issues with the dough being crumbly. I did add salt (1/4 tsp) and vanilla (1/2 tsp) and next time I would probably add a little bit more as the cookie by itself was a little bit bland.
We used to call these "Jammies"......very good
Perfectly, delicious. Soft crumble, not too sweet. Hubby devoured them…A definite recipe keeper!
Delicious! I did not change a thing! I will make these often!!!
We sprinkled a little powder sugar on the finished cookies. Easy and delicious!
Yummy
Easy and they have been a family favorite for years
I wasted time and money. They are all crumpled. I followed the recipe.

Delicious! I did add vanilla extract, salt and used one whole egg as some suggested and I was glad I did! They are scrumptious! They will certainly become one of my favorites for my Christmas cookie baking tradition!

Great cookie recipe with some minimal additions. I added a dash of salt and vanilla to add a little flavor and balance and I beat the butter and sugar until light and fluffy before adding the eggs. With these small changes the cookies came out delicious with a nice texture and crumb that my family really enjoyed!
So good. Added the 2t of vanilla & 1/4t of salt. Recommend raspberry jam. For extra finesse, drizzle white chocolate on top.
it is VERY yummy and yum in the yummy ez yay
loved the cookie but only made 9 super small ones. But for the taste, GREAT JOB
Delicious, soft and very moreish, exactly what I was looking for to make Lemon thumbprint cookies and they turned out fantastic! ??
These are the best cookies. Made rhubarb and apple. I added a little cinnamon and 2 Teaspoon of vanilla. yummy!
these are so amazing, they simply melt in your mouth! I filled half with fig jam, half with plum jam, then glazed them.

They were so yummy! Everybody in my family loved it and it was so easy and fun to make! In the beginning, my dough was very crumbly and didn't stay together because I didn't add in the flour gradually. But then, I added a 1/2 cup water while mixing and it turned out perfect!
Loved these cookies! I made some with jam and some I flattened and without the jam (hubby doesn't like the jam) they were awesome. Definetly a keeper!
Pretty good. Easy to make. The cookies are a bit bland.

I love Lindser cookies and never made them before... tried this recipe and it was a huge hit with everyone. I've made 5 batches in just a few days because of the high demand. Hah. It is also really easy to make. Only thing I had to tweak is the baking time - i upped that to 13 minutes. Thank you for sharing this jam
Very bland, no flavor. Won’t be making again.
I split the batter in half and added cocoa powder to half. Came out great
Excellent. Love the buttery taste, and texture is silky... will make more of them.

I love this recipe because it translates super well to vegan. I mostly keep the recipe as it is but use plant butter and omit the egg yolks. Instead, i make one egg from Bob's Red Mill Egg Replacer. I added a teaspoon of vanilla, brought the temp down to 350 and baked them a little longer. I used fresh fruit in which I ground up in the food processor with just a little sugar added to the fruit. These were so delicious that my vegan kids and grandkids devoured, leaving very little for grandma, lol.
Cookie was good but jam didn't cook off enough moisture. experimenting with amounts.
easy and good

I've made these cookies several times, and they were a hit! I was surprised to read some of the comments stating the cookies were bland. I do add vanilla to the recipe, almond or anise would also work. I love these cookies with coffee. The only downside, they are too good, so I don't make them that often! LOL Will be making these for my son's wedding. The Pittsburgh Cookie Table is real!!!
Tasted great, easy to make
Really good and simple

Tasted okay with additions of nutmeg, cinnamon, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Recipe is poorly written—not specific or detailed enough to yield consistent results. Dough was crumbly, cookies remained soft even when cooled. I have nothing against soft cookies—in fact, I prefer soft varieties—but butter cookies should be crunchy. First batch, I used the end of a pen to poke the holes and add apple butter. Second batch, I used my finger and had to reshape and work a ton to keep the crumbly dough together, but that method did yield a better looking result. I added strawberry jam to those ones. They tasted pretty yummy.
Easy and delicious. As other reviews recommended, we added some salt and vanilla extract and it came out great.

Bland? These cookies are anything but bland. These cookies have replaced the birthday cake for my daughter. She loves and expects these cookies every year for her birthday. We both love them because they are just the right amount of sweetness.
Incredible! Soo Good! I used seedless jam on mine and they excellent!
I thought this was perfect- the cookies turned out very soft with a flavor like a shortbread. I used apricot, raspberry, and guava jelly for a variety. Thanks for the recipe!
Easy recipe, love it. I didn't have any jam though, but it still tastes great.
Too much butter. Really greasy rolling dough into balls. Ok if you don’t mind getting your hands dirty.

AMAZING! I’m not sure why some people reviewed the cookies as bland. They weren’t bland at all in my opinion. I followed the recipe exactly, didn’t change a thing. I did use high quality butter and a good jam. The recipe was quick and easy and I loved them.
this recipe is awsome
I filled some with apricot jam, some with fig jam and some with Nutella...
Love these! Reminded me of my childhood so I had to try! They were delicious with raspberry preserve and even did some with peanut butter and Nutella!

Fabulous recipe--this is a family favorite of ours now (especially at holiday time!). Only adjustment I do is adding a little bit of vanilla extract to the dough. Absolutely delicious and so super easy!
Added 2 tsp of vanilla and a pinch of salt to the recipe. :)
not my personal favourite but they turned out great

turned out to be a lot of people's favorite.
I used blueberry jam and will have to make them more than just for Christmas haha

I made these this past Christmas and everyone liked them. Will make them again. I did add 2 tsps of vanilla to the recipe to give more flavor. I used the strawberry jam that comes in a squeeze bottle for ease of adding the jam exactly where I wanted it.
These were very easy and came out perfect! I used peach preserves, BTW.
I read a review from another user that said to add vanilla and salt and to use a whole egg instead of two egg yolks. I did this and they turned out wonderfully. The family loved them at Christmas.

Delicious, buttery flavor, easy to make. I rolled some in chopped walnuts, used cherry jam and strawberry jam.
I preferred the cookies without the nuts. Will definitely include these in my Christmas cookie lineup next year.
made these but added 1/2 t. almond extract to the dough and used the almond icing recipe from the Raspberry and Almond Shortbread cookie recipe to drizzle over the top. They are yummy!!
I make these every year for the holidays. I put any number of jams in them and they are always a hit. Not too sweet and pretty to serve.

This is a good basic thumbprint cookie recipe. You can use this as the base. I would recommend making the dough and then chilling it for at least 20 minutes, adding more flour as needed (you want it very soft but not too sticky). Adding vanilla to the dough is personal preference. 
After rolling the dough into balls, you need to dip it into an egg white bath, then bake it.
This recipe also takes between 10-12 minutes, not 8-10.

We were looking for a jam filled cookie recipe for a party and decided to make these - even doubled the recipe. I did add 2T of almond extract as some reviews said the cookie itself was a bit bland - these were not bland and delicious. Now even though I doubled the recipe, it only made 3 1/2 dozen cookies as I used a small scoop to keep size of the cookies uniform, rolled them into a ball and made thumb print in palm of hand. This made a decent size 'well' to put preserves in and a bit of a thicker cookie too. Also, put the made but not cooked cookies into the refrigerator for about 5 minutes before cooking them to cool down the butter again - the cookies did not spread out as much. Needless to say, I ended up making another double batch of these as Hubby and kids (and me too) got into them that night and needed to replenish them!

I make a similar recipe but lost it and found this as a replacement. I doubled the recipe and added a tiny amount of almond extract. And a little pinch of salt. Just because that’s how I like it. Great simple recipe.

I had to add almost a cup more of flour than what the recipe called for to make the dough rollable. Also added vanilla extract into the dough- great tasting cookies though and quick to make up and bake!

Made these with my 5 year old daughter who just loved making the thumb holes! We used unsalted butter so added a little salt and also added some vanilla extract for added flavour. We use our homemade strawberry jam and they turned out great. I am happy to have made a double batch.
Very easy and they turned out great! I added a little salt and vanilla like other reviewers. I did half with raspberry preserves and half with blackberry preserves.
pretty tasty, with the right jam! i had to cook for nearly twice the length of time listed here, though.
Dough didn't form with specified quantities. Meassured and did twice with same results. They don't bake well and the dough is all grainy and doesn't hold toguether. Never making again.

First time posting and first time making cookies from this app! After reading previous reviews I decided to add 1/4 tsp salt and 2 tsp vanilla....I kept the rest the same! I used Black Cherry preserves...so delicious!

Took one of the reviewers advice and added 1/2 tsp of salt and 2 tsp of vanilla to add more flavor. Also after a rolled the dough into balls and used my finger to make the well, I gently pushed down the cookies with a flat-bottomed cup. I re-shapes the holes a bit and used another reviewer’s advice by filling the jam (I used strawberry) in a plastic bag and cutting a small corner off to squeeze the jam into the wells.
Made these with apricot preserves and 3/4 teaspoon of almond extract in the cookie dough and they turned out great, will definitely make again!
AMAZING! my husband and I loved them.

I made these with my 9 and 5 year old daughters. It was so easy they could do it by themselves and they had so much fun with the textures of the jams. I used pineapple and strawberry. The cookie was very good, not to sweet, and the strawberry preserves made the perfect combination, the pineapple was just to bland for us. They were gone in less than a day..lol..next time I will be doing a double recipe.
The jam kind of bubbled off. They tasted really good, but they looked like a crime scene.
They tasted like burnt butter,but looked pretty
I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out great! I served them at a graduation party and they went fast!
Made some for my husband. He loved them !!
Easy and so tasty. Melt-in-the-mouth. Great with morning coffee or tea.

I love the texture of the dough when rolling into the balls. I have made other recipes like this where the dough crumbled too much. I baked these on the least amount of suggested time, and they were perfect texture. The only negative comment I have was that the cookie itself did not have enough flavor, but when you take a bite with the jam, I guess it complimented it. Next time I will add some vanilla extract as other folks did. They look really fancy on a platter! ( put a very, very light drizzle of icing on them to dress them up.
It was so easy to make. I loved it!
these are delicious and easy. Perfect for the holidays or just whenever you want a quick easy cookie.

Simple and easy and was amazing with my homemade marionberry freezer jam. Like any recipe I just adjusted to what I know our likes are. I doubled the recipe and added 1 tablespoon of pure vanilla extract from Mexico and they were delicious. Thanks for the recipe.

I don't know how to rate these. They taste fine for what they are. However, they look so pretty and festive when you make a platter for the holidays. This alone makes you want to eat them. And you have so many options for the preserves/color.
I make these at the holidays or when I know people are coming over. I use Raspberry Jam or sometimes Apricot Jam.
I make these at the holidays or when I know people are coming over. I use Raspberry Jam or sometimes Apricot Jam.
These are so good but I had to bake them for 15 minutes instead of 10
Very tasty. Kind of sweet but I’ll make them again. And I’ll add some citrus to pump up the cookie.
I doubled the recipe because when I make cookies I expect them to last two or three days but this recipe only made three dozen cookies so next time I will need to quadruple or more the recipe.
So easy and they are so good they just disapear!

Thank you for sharing this lovely, simple recipe! I've been making these for years now, and they've become a sort of staple... Relatives and friends are always buying new types of jam and begging me to make these cookies with them. No matter how sugary the jam is, it helps that the dough is not too sweet.

These were easy to make, look pretty on the plate, and are very tasty. I used lemon curd as the filling for half the batch, and strawberry jam for the other half.

I added half a teaspoon of vanilla extract, which gave them a nice flavor.
So simple and easy to make. The cookies had a lot of flavor. This will be on my go to list.

Very easy but there is no way this recipe yields 36. I got 25. Any smaller and they would be nonexistent. I also used a dash of vanilla and a drop of almond extract. I made one batch with sugar and one with Splenda. No noticeable difference.

I make this cookie every Christmas but don't have a specific recipe printed - I usually just find one with good reviews. This is an easy cookie and not far off from similar ones, but this needed salt (which I added) and vanilla or almond (I added vanilla). I just felt these tasted really "flour-y" and less buttery... Probably won't use this specific recipe again.
As is would be very bland. Took the advice of others and added 1 tsp salt (I use unsalted butter) and 2 tsp vanilla. Definitely more buttery than regular thumbprint cookies.

I made these for a holiday party, and they were definitely well received. They were delicious and very, very easy to make! I followed a few of the other tips, using 1 whole egg (vs. 2 eggs whites), added 1/4 tsp salt, and experimented with 1 tsp maple syrup for a little added flavor. I used the back of a 1/2 tsp to poke a perfect (and deeper) circle in the middle, which helped keep the jam in nicely. After filling with jam, I put the sheets of cookies into the freezer for about 20 minutes before placing into the oven- this way they did not flatten while cooking. I will certainly make again, thank you for this recipe.
Great basic recipe, must at 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla or almond extract for flavor (or 1/4 each like me!)

I ABSOLUTELY do not understand why these thumbprint cookies got a bad rap either!! There is someone else who made this comment first and I am just agreeing with her!
They are easy to make, 1 Bowl, find your absolutely most favourite jam ever and use it because it will make them just that much more Amazing!! As per McKenzie’s review:
https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/25100/jam-filled-butter-cookies/reviews/4531315/.
 My Mother and I would make thumbprint cookies, Every Christmas, the ones with nuts on the outside. I followed alot of McKenzie's suggestions and they turned out as Perfect as the ones My Mother and I would make!! They were SOOO good that my Roommate who was going back to Mexico took the majority back with her because, YES, they were that good!! Follow the recipe and they will turn out perfectly... Just like mine!! :)
PS Merry Almost Christmas :)
Added a pinch of nutmeg for extra hint of flavor. They ARE marvelous.

These are awesome! I put a dollop of chocolate ganache in the center. Will have to double next time so they will last more than one day. Family ate them up. Thanks for sharing my new easy go-to cookies.
The cookie was blend, but loved the texture of the cookie. Maybe on the next batch I'll apply some kind of zest to give the cookie some kind of taste.

Since I wanted chocolate thumbprint cookies and couldn't find a good recipe, I altered this one a bit and it turned out great! 
First I used 1 whole egg instead of 2 egg yolks. Then I substituted 1/4 cup of the flour for 1/4 cup of Hershey's Special Dark Cocoa Powder. This turned the cookies almost an alarming shade of brown/black, but they tasted excellent! I also added a touch of baking powder for good measure.
So Easy..So Simple and So delicious.... thank you for the recipe
These were very easy to make, yet tasted like store-bought cookies I used to eat when I was younger. I will definitely make these again! :-)

This recipe is great, but I did two batches, one with a tablespoon of vanilla added and one without, and the vanilla makes a Huge difference. Also, I used two whole eggs, I didn't bother separating, so it might have been a little sticky, but I just work fast and it's fine.

Started getting compliments after some substitutions. I use 1/2 cup almond flour, 3/4 cup whole wheat flour, with the remainder 1/2 cup being all purpose. Also roll balls in finely crushed walnuts before depression for jam is made. Adds a great nutty flavor.
I made these and absolutely loved it! I used a lemon curd as a filling rather than a jam.
